Award.AwardTitle: Physical Chemistry of Macromolecules as Probed by High Resolution Solid State NMR
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Kurt Zilm at Yale University will develop novel Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) techniques to study the physical chemistry of large molecules in a site-specific manner. Advances in dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP), which enhances NMR signals by over 100-fold, will be adapted to microliter size samples. This has the potential to make feasible biophysical studies on recombinant membrane proteins with as little as 100 nanograms of material. Other methods will be developed to determine distances the order of 10 Angstroms by simple NMR relaxation measurements. These techniques will be applied to understand how mutations in visual pigments change the structure of the retinal chromophore, and for observing the dynamics of buried water molecules in proteins.

Broader impacts of this research include expanding the biophysical chemistry toolbox, and the training of students as instrument building experimentalists at the interface of biology and chemistry. Professor Zilm is actively involved in the recruitment of underrepresented students in natural science research through the Yale University Science and Technology Research Scholars program, and as the host of chemistry laboratory open houses for local high school classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research in this grant explored two broad themes, I) the study of protein dynamics and structure by solid state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) methods, and II) development of new NMR instrumentation and methodology for such studies in proteins and other biological systems.  

    Molecular motions play an integral role in the physical chemistry of proteins. Atomic nuclei possess magnetic moments, and when they move the accompanying time dependent magnetic fields affect how rapidly the nuclear magnetization either relaxes or is exchanged between differentially polarized nuclei. The larger the motion amplitude and the closer the motional frequency to the NMR frequencies, the faster the ensuing relaxation rates. When NMR is applied to microcrystalline proteins, the overall molecular tumbling that dominates NMR relaxation in solution is quenched, and directly reports on internal local motions. In this grant we developed methods and a theoretical framework to relate the 15N relaxation rates for individual amides to the amplitude and frequencies of motions all along the protein backbone. Similar measurements for 1Hs quantified the diffusion of water molecules and exchangeable protons throughout proteins, and related cross relaxation quantitatively to exchange rates for labile sidechain sites.  In addition we developed a method to use 13C NMR relaxation to measure distances over six Angstroms. We demonstrated that slowly relaxing 13C in carbonyl positions would be relaxed by efficient cross relaxation with 13C in rapidly rotating methyl groups, and the rate enhancement provided a direct measure of the distance between the carbonyl and methyl group 13C relaxation sink. Dynamics were studied by NMR in model proteins, including a bacteriorhodopsin mutant engineered for optical memory applications.

    In this grant we also pursued approaches to NMR sensitivity improvement. The first was to apply pulsed field gradient (pfg) pulses to accelerate data acquisition in multi-dimensional NMR. Because evolution in the additional time dimensions is indirectly detected, several experiments using different phases are co-added for each indirect time point for proper coherence seection. In 3D or 4D experiments all the phases needed can result in week or month long acquisition times. Pfg pulses often can eliminate the need for phase cycling, greatly speeding up data acquisition. In solids NMR the problem is the sample must be spun rapidly to provide high resolution. For pfg pulses to work in coherence transfer, the sample must appear as if static. This can be accomplished by using rotation synchronous pfg pulses, however the position of the rotor must be reproducible on successive rotations to within fractions of a micron. In this grant we invented a method to characterize the spinning and provide for its control. The ceramic rotor readily holds a static surface charge. When this moves it will induce a triboelectric signal in an antenna, encoding all aspects of the motion. A key discovery was the Fourier transform of this signal discriminates axial and conical motions from the desired cylindrical rotation. The FT signal analysis can be done in real time, and we demonstrated this could be used to optimize pfg echo performance.
